Behavior if the initial state of motion is outside of the kinematic boundaries

In case the initial state of motion is not within the given maximum values for velocity and acceleration , two different behaviors are offered for the target position-based on-line trajectory generation algorithm. This behavior can be specified with the flag RMLPositionFlags::BehaviorIfInitialStateBreachesConstraints, which can have two values:

  • RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_FAST (default): This way, a trajectory will be generated that brings the system back into the boundaries as fast as possible. However, the intermediate acceleration values, at which the maximum velocity values of are reached, will be unequal to zero. This may lead to an undesired overshooting of the generated position and/or velocity signal.

  • RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_AT_ZERO_ACCELERATION: This way, the maximum velocity values of are reached at zero velocity. Getting back into the boundaries takes more time compared to RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_FAST, however, it is possible to keep moving at the maximum velocity values of without position or velocity overshootings.

The following input values for one axis only illustrate the two different behaviors:




Difference between the two flags RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_FAST (blue) and RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_AT_ZERO_ACCELERATION (red).



The diagram shows the velocity progression of two trajectories for a one-degree-of-freedom system that were generated with the same input values , , and . Only the flag RMLPositionFlags::BehaviorIfInitialStateBreachesConstraints is different: the red trajectory was generated using RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_AT_ZERO_ACCELERATION and the blue one with RMLPositionFlags::GET_INTO_BOUNDARIES_FAST. The initial velocity is outside of its constraint .

While the blue motion gets back into the boundaries faster than the red one (0.403 seconds and 0.552 seconds), the red trajectory does not have an overshooting (please not that the overshooting may also lead to negative velocity values!). In this example, the red trajectory reaches the target state before the blue trajectory (2.535 seconds and 2.668 seconds).
